intro: Psyllocarpus galioides, commonly known as the narrow-leafed sycamore, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Fabaceae, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant has a shallow root system and thrives in moist, well-drained soils. It is often found in floodplain forests and is adapted to periodic flooding. Its botanical features make it an important component of riparian ecosystems.
